meta.title: Tender points, trigger points, and Chapman points

content:
Introduction

Tender points, trigger points, and Chapman points are distinct types of palpable regions, each with unique characteristics and clinical implications.  This article discusses their definitions, clinical significance, and therapeutic applications, including osteopathic manipulative treatment.

Tender points



Tender points are small, discrete areas of tenderness that form in a muscle belly or corresponding tendon.  These points are a manifestation of sustained input from hyperactive muscle spindles caused by nearby somatic dysfunction.  They do not produce referred pain when palpated, differentiating them from trigger points (discussed next).  They also differ from the widespread painful points characteristic of fibromyalgia, a systemic condition with distinct diagnostic criteria and underlying mechanisms.  Over 200 tender points are mapped by anatomic region.  Naming conventions typically reflect location (eg, anterior vs posterior) and region (eg, cervical, thoracic, lumbar, rib, pelvic, extremity); for example, AC and PC refer to anterior and posterior cervical tender points.



Tender points are typically treated with counterstrain, an indirect, passive technique that reduces tension and pain by holding the affected muscles in a shortened/relaxed position for 90 seconds (except for maverick tender points, which require the muscle to be lengthened).  Counterstrain resets the reflexive neuromuscular output from the muscle spindle that is facilitating the abnormally tense muscle/tendon.



For example, a posterior lumbar tender point located on the left spinous or transverse process of the lumbar vertebrae is treated by extending, sidebending away, and rotating away from the tender point (ie, E, SA, RA) (

Tender points and counterstrain are discussed in further detail in a separate article.

Trigger points



Trigger points are areas within a taut band of skeletal muscle that are tender to palpation and often refer pain to nearby structures.  Trigger points often develop from excessive muscle strain due to repetitive microtrauma, which facilitates a reflex from the muscle to the spinal cord and then back to other muscles in the area (ie, somatosomatic reflex).  The pattern of referred pain is specific to the affected muscle group (eg, upper trapezius referring pain to the occiput and shoulder).



Trigger points are treated with a variety of methods, including stretching (which may be facilitated by application of a vapocoolant spray), injection of a local anesthetic (eg, lidocaine), and myofascial release/muscle energy.

Chapman points



Chapman points are specific neurolymphatic reflex points located in predictable anatomic locations on the body's anterior and posterior surfaces.  They are thought to be due to impaired local lymphatic drainage leading to inflammation of the surrounding fascia, resulting in neurolymphatic gangliform contractions.  These 2-3 mm, tender nodules may aid in the diagnosis of certain visceral diseases.  In general, organs have associated anterior and posterior Chapman points (

figure 1
,
figure 2
).  These points serve primarily diagnostic roles, guiding visceral-focused lymphatic treatments.  For example, the gallbladder Chapman point (located at the right seventh intercostal space) may aid in diagnosing cholecystitis.  A list of Chapman points is provided in a separate article.



Chapman points are treated through gentle rotary pressure or circular massage, intended to normalize lymphatic flow and facilitate reflexive improvements in associated visceral organ function.

Summary



Tender points, trigger points, and Chapman points are osteopathic physical examination tools with distinct pathophysiologic and clinical characteristics.  Tender points facilitate indirect muscle treatments, trigger points guide direct myofascial interventions for referred pain, and Chapman points inform visceral assessments and treatments (
